content.webTitle: Landa award 2013: a deserving winner but a weak show

fields.headline: Landa award 2013: a deserving winner but a weak show
fields.bodyText: Angelica Mesiti’s Citizen’s Band was announced winner of the bi-annual, $25,000 Anne Landa award for video and new media arts for 2013 on Thursday. The piece does one of the things that video art can do best – expand cinema into multiple time frames and points of view. Documenting the musical performances of people far from their homes, the four-screen work plays out the water drumming of a woman from Cameroon in a swimming pool, an Algerian man playing a broken Casio keyboard on the Paris Metro, a Mongolian man playing a stringed instrument and throat singing on a city street and a Sudanese taxi driver whistling a melancholy tune. That Mesiti’s video installation has taken the Art Gallery of NSW’s acquisitive award in what must be the weakest year of the prize thus far should not detract from the fact that Citizen’s Band is an elegant, beautiful and affecting piece. The cinematography is restrained, the editing unobtrusive. It’s a great work. The Landa is now a decade old: launched in 2004, it highlighted some of the energetic video work that was being produced by a generation of mostly younger artists in Sydney, Brisbane and Melbourne, while the acquisitive part of the prize also helped to bolster the AGNSW’s collection. Its first few iterations showcased a selection of curated finalists, each of whom could have easily and deservedly won the prize. Early winners such as David Rozetsky’s Untouchable in 2004 and Monika Tichacek’s The Shadowers in 2006 tilted the prize toward elaborate video-installation pieces. In many ways, 2013 Landa curator Charlotte Day has taken things back to basics: gone are the huge installations and furniture pieces of early years and instead we have some very modest installations, sculptures and screen works. Day decided to look at the idea of performance in video and new media: there are artists doing things and then recording them, like Kate Mitchell’s jumping-through-glass multiscreen sculpture Lucky Break, or Lauren Brincat’s High Horse, where the artist stands for ages on the back of a horse; and artists recording other people doing things, as in James Newitt’s We Are The People, a documentation of a staged demonstration, and Laresa Kosloff’s Eternal Situation, a video that documents visitors wandering through the ‘old paintings’ section of the AGNSW to Whitney Houston warbling I Have Nothing Without You. On one level this was an inevitable curatorial angle to take, since performance-video has been one of the strongest aspects of contemporary art in Australia, and there are many artists young and old making compelling performance based works. But one can hardly claim that this practice is in any way new – or "renewed" as Day carefully claims in the catalogue. The recording of performance by film or video, through sound or by documentation, is at least 50 years old – longer in the case of cinema and photography – and some pieces such as Alicia Frankovich’s Free Time/Opportune Spectator, a wall of framed texts and a daily, scheduled performance, are virtually “media” free. That stretch of curatorial logic undermines the show with a selection of mostly lacklustre works that are either pastiches of much better works by better artists elsewhere – Newitt’s work looks pretty weak compared to Jeremy Deller’s Battle of Orgreave from 2001 – or are not very good examples of work by talented artists, Mitchell’s work an unfortunate example. The cramped staging of the show, a far cry from the Landa’s early days as a major event at the gallery, adds to the exhibition’s shortcomings, with unfortunate sound bleeds from that bloody Whitney Houston song wafting into to the rest of the show, and hardly enough room to step back and consider individual works. Maybe the Landa’s next outing in 2015 will feature real new media, or perhaps it’ll just settle back into framing the impressive practice of Australian video art, and not worry too much about the chimerical idea of trying to justify the works as ‘new’. As Mesiti’s Citizen’s Band demonstrates, there’s still plenty of life in the medium yet.
